<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 277, 171, 292]]<|/det|>
## PHYSICS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 297, 393, 313]]<|/det|>
Paper 2 AS Level Structured Questions  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 338, 415, 354]]<|/det|>
Candidates answer on the Question Paper.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 359, 368, 374]]<|/det|>
No Additional Materials are required.  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 390, 388, 407]]<|/det|>
## READ THESE INSTRUCTIONS FIRST  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 416, 715, 490]]<|/det|>
Write your centre number, candidate number and name on all the work you hand in. Write in dark blue or black pen. You may use an HB pencil for any diagrams or graphs. Do not use staples, paper clips, glue or correction fluid. DO NOT WRITE IN ANY BARCODES.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 500, 255, 516]]<|/det|>
Answer all questions.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 526, 769, 558]]<|/det|>
Electronic calculators may be used. You may lose marks if you do not show your working or if you do not use appropriate units.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[92, 567, 760, 597]]<|/det|>
At the end of the examination, fasten all your work securely together. The number of marks is given in brackets [ ] at the end of each question or part question.

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[82, 73, 124, 88]]<|/det|>
## Data  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[79, 103, 640, 560]]<|/det|>
speed of light in free space \(c = 3.00\times 10^{8}\mathrm{m s}^{- 1}\) permeability of free space \(\mu_{0} = 4\pi \times 10^{- 7}\mathrm{Hm}^{- 1}\) permittivity of free space \(\epsilon_{0} = 8.85\times 10^{- 12}\mathrm{Fm}^{- 1}\) \((\frac{1}{4\pi\epsilon_{0}} = 8.99\times 10^{9}\mathrm{mF}^{- 1})\) elementary charge \(e = 1.60\times 10^{- 19}\mathrm{C}\) the Planck constant \(h = 6.63\times 10^{- 34}\mathrm{Js}\) unified atomic mass unit \(1u = 1.66\times 10^{- 27}\mathrm{kg}\) rest mass of electron \(m_{\mathrm{e}} = 9.11\times 10^{- 31}\mathrm{kg}\) rest mass of proton \(m_{\mathrm{p}} = 1.67\times 10^{- 27}\mathrm{kg}\) molar gas constant \(R = 8.31\mathrm{JK}^{- 1}\mathrm{mol}^{- 1}\) the Avogadro constant \(N_{\mathrm{A}} = 6.02\times 10^{23}\mathrm{mol}^{- 1}\) the Boltzmann constant \(k = 1.38\times 10^{- 23}\mathrm{JK}^{- 1}\) gravitational constant \(G = 6.67\times 10^{- 11}\mathrm{Nm}^{2}\mathrm{kg}^{- 2}\) acceleration of free fall \(g = 9.81\mathrm{ms}^{- 2}\)

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[440, 107, 561, 144]]<|/det|>
\[s = ut + \frac{1}{2} at^{2}\] \[\nu^{2} = u^{2} + 2as\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[440, 163, 527, 180]]<|/det|>
\[W = p\Delta V\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[445, 195, 537, 225]]<|/det|>
\[\phi = -\frac{Gm}{r}\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[445, 235, 525, 252]]<|/det|>
\[p = \rho gh\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[445, 262, 561, 295]]<|/det|>
\[p = \frac{1}{3}\frac{Nm}{V}\langle c^2\rangle\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[445, 305, 537, 322]]<|/det|>
\[a = -\omega^2 x\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[445, 339, 616, 375]]<|/det|>
\[\nu = \nu_{0}\cos \omega t\] \[\nu = \pm \omega \sqrt{(\chi_{0}^{2} - x^{2})}\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[445, 384, 537, 420]]<|/det|>
\[f_{0} = \frac{f_{s}V}{\nu \pm V_{s}}\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[445, 430, 537, 465]]<|/det|>
\[V = \frac{Q}{4\pi\epsilon_{0}r}\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[425, 472, 628, 490]]<|/det|>
\[1 / C = 1 / C_{1} + 1 / C_{2} + \ldots\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[445, 504, 596, 523]]<|/det|>
\[C = C_{1} + C_{2} + \ldots\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[440, 533, 527, 560]]<|/det|>
\[W = \frac{1}{2} QV\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[445, 574, 532, 592]]<|/det|>
\[I = A n v q\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[440, 609, 596, 626]]<|/det|>
\[R = R_{1} + R_{2} + \ldots\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[425, 640, 628, 658]]<|/det|>
\[1 / R = 1 / R_{1} + 1 / R_{2} + \ldots\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[440, 672, 517, 705]]<|/det|>
\[V_{\mathrm{H}} = \frac{BI}{ntq}\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[445, 720, 560, 737]]<|/det|>
\[x = x_{0}\sin \omega t\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[445, 752, 579, 770]]<|/det|>
\[x = x_{0}\exp (-\lambda t)\]  

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[445, 780, 536, 814]]<|/det|>
\[\lambda = \frac{0.693}{t_{\frac{1}{2}}}\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 195, 848, 213]]<|/det|>
A potential difference of \(0.60 \text{V}\) is applied across a resistor of resistance \(4.0 \text{G} \Omega\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 225, 547, 244]]<|/det|>
Calculate the current, in pA, in the resistor.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[505, 380, 920, 400]]<|/det|>
<form>current = .................................................... pA [2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 413, 146, 432]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 413, 920, 446]]<|/det|>
The energy \(E\) transferred when charge \(Q\) moves through an electrical component is given by the equation

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[467, 459, 534, 477]]<|/det|>
\[E = QV\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 490, 631, 508]]<|/det|>
where \(V\) is the potential difference across the component.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 520, 740, 539]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[470, 752, 920, 771]]<|/det|>
<form>SI base units .................................................... [3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[843, 783, 920, 801]]<|/det|>

<label>2</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 72, 144, 91]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 72, 920, 121]]<|/det|>
A resultant force \(F\) moves an object of mass \(m\) through distance \(s\) in a straight line. The force gives the object an acceleration \(a\) so that its speed changes from initial speed \(u\) to final speed \(v\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 133, 183, 152]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 133, 395, 152]]<|/det|>
State an expression for:

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 164, 220, 182]]<|/det|>
<label>1.</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[230, 164, 667, 183]]<|/det|>
the work \(W\) done by the force, in terms of \(a\), \(m\) and \(s\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[547, 240, 920, 259]]<|/det|>
<form>W = ....................................................... [1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 272, 220, 291]]<|/det|>
<label>2.</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[230, 272, 539, 291]]<|/det|>
the distance \(s\), in terms of \(a\), \(u\) and \(v\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[554, 350, 920, 369]]<|/det|>
<form>s = ............................................................ [1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 381, 181, 400]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 381, 845, 400]]<|/det|>
Use your answers in **(i)** to show that the kinetic energy of the object is given by

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[339, 405, 656, 435]]<|/det|>
\[\text{kinetic energy} = \frac{1}{2}\times \text{mass}\times \text{(speed)}^2.\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 443, 374, 462]]<|/det|>
Explain your working.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 598, 920, 617]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 630, 146, 648]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[151, 630, 920, 664]]<|/det|>
A ball of mass \(0.040\mathrm{kg}\) is projected into the air from horizontal ground, as illustrated in Fig. 2.1.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 873, 920, 907]]<|/det|>
The ball is launched from a point X with a kinetic energy of 4.5 J. At point Y, the ball has a speed of \(9.5 \text{m s}^{-1}\). Air resistance is negligible.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 73, 181, 91]]<|/det|>
<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 72, 841, 91]]<|/det|>
For the movement of the ball from X to Y, draw a solid line on Fig. 2.1 to show:

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[193, 102, 541, 121]]<|/det|>
1. the distance moved (label this line D)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 133, 222, 151]]<|/det|>
<label>2.</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[230, 133, 524, 152]]<|/det|>
the displacement (label this line S).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 875, 92]]<|/det|>
A cylindrical disc of mass \(0.24\mathrm{kg}\) has a circular cross-sectional area \(A\), as shown in Fig. 3.1.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 247, 920, 297]]<|/det|>
The disc is on horizontal ground, as shown in Fig. 3.2. A force X of magnitude \(8.9 \text{N}\) acts on the disc in a direction of \(30^{\circ}\) to the horizontal. The disc moves at a constant speed of \(0.60 \text{m s}^{-1}\) along the ground.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 310, 144, 327]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[153, 310, 648, 329]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[415, 432, 920, 451]]<|/det|>
<form>rate of doing work = .................................................... W [2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[114, 463, 146, 482]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 463, 912, 482]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 494, 551, 512]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[551, 680, 920, 699]]<|/det|>

<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[195, 758, 384, 777]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[196, 789, 920, 808]]<|/det|>
<form>............................................................................................................ [1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[149, 820, 181, 838]]<|/det|>
<label>(ii)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[195, 820, 559, 838]]<|/det|>
the name of the body on which force Y acts.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[845, 880, 920, 898]]<|/det|>
<mark>[Total: 7]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 73, 94, 90]]<|/det|>
<label>4</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 747, 91]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 87, 507, 106]]<|/det|>

(not to scale)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 422, 920, 457]]<|/det|>
Each plate has a length of \(2.0 \text{m}\). The potential difference between the plates is \(900 \text{V}\). The electric field between the plates is uniform.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 469, 920, 520]]<|/det|>
A negatively charged sand particle is released from rest at point X, which is a horizontal distance of \(0.080 \text{m}\) from the top of the positively charged plate. The particle then travels in a straight line and collides with the positively charged plate at its lowest point Y, as illustrated in Fig. 4.1.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 532, 146, 551]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 532, 747, 551]]<|/det|>

<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 655, 813, 673]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[111, 715, 143, 734]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 660, 920, 693]]<|/det|>

<label>(i)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 724, 91]]<|/det|>
A vertical tube of length \(0.60 \text{m}\) is open at both ends, as shown in Fig. 5.1.

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[354, 100, 640, 349]]<|/det|>
